Fields.DialogueText: Matelot - have you seen the ship's Belle?
Oui, Capitaine. She's like a vision at the prow, kneeling in prayer as we begin another day's labors for God and country.

Fields.MenuText: Technically, it's the whole world.
Yeah, that's great. She should be on the bridge.
Right. Thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Oui.

Fields.MenuText: No pressure, right?
Carry on.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, Capitaine!
Maybe not for you...
Carry on, sailor.
I have two thoughts, Capitaine.
Do you, now?
Thought one - perhaps she thinks this is more important.
Uh-huh. And thought two?
If someone's going to tell her she should be somewhere else, better you than me.
*ALARM*
Heck of a way to start a day.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? About the other day... pardonnez-moi. I let myself be distracted. It won't happen again.

Fields.MenuText: You're allowed to be lost in thought for a few minutes, as long as you're alert when we need you.
Glad to hear it.
Stop. It was already forgotten.

Fields.DialogueText: And I wasn't.
We survived the fight. I'd say you did okay.
That's very kind, Capitaine.
I should say, I've been preoccupied with our next mission. Or, more to the point, with trying to guess what it might be. Have we received orders?
Well, there are some in the French establishment who've requested we patrol the Manche just to annoy the British-
Heh.
But I'm pretty sure it was in jest. Last I heard, the plan was to stick to the Mediterranean.
I should probably add that there's been some talk about the League carving out special roles for "culturally significant" Belles - like yourself, obviously - to keep your patrol routes close to home.
I'm a warship, Capitaine. I'm significant for my guns, not my symbolism.

Well, a cynical captain might say that their real concern was keeping notably loyal Belles around to facilitate the transfer of French troops between the mainland and Algeria as the land war requires.
... Je comprends, Capitaine.
May I ask what my commanding officer thinks?
Your commanding officer's job is to fight the Morganas.
D'accord. I think you're about to get your chance.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Morganas may be engaging us within the hour - possibly much sooner.
The group that's been harassing Corsica? That's convenient.
That said, good job picking them up. We'll be ready.
Actually, Delusion called me. She does that every so often. Or *versions* of her call me every so often, I suppose.

Fields.MenuText: I... was not expecting that.
Are you saying she's some kind of double agent?
So this could be a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: Have you ever had a conversation with Delusion?
Beyond the standard pre-battle babbling?
Oui. If her mind is organized enough to set out a trap - or to execute anyone else's - she hides it very well.
All the same, let's be ready for the worst.
Evidemment.
Non. Not at all.
She hates me. But, of course, she's lonely.
In one of our earliest battles, when we were shouting at each other as we got into position, I said something about her not being the only one who hears voices.
Apparently she decided we were kindred spirits.
That's got to be unsettling.
Right. If they're coming from the general direction of Corsica, and if they're in radio range, I assume it's not going to be too hard to intercept them.
With the navigator's permission, Capitaine, I have a course in mind.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Qu’est-ce que je peux faire pour vous?
Sorry - I don't mean to interrupt your prayer book time. We just need to schedule a few minutes to go over those new reports from the Balearic Islands.
Don't worry, Capitaine. I think it's important that the crew see me out here, looking out for them, but I'm not really doing anything I can't interrupt.

Fields.MenuText: You're supposed to be off-duty now, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: No such thing.

Fields.MenuText: Really? What would your namesake say?

Fields.DialogueText: Je ne sais pas. I've never met her.

Fields.MenuText: Fair enough.

Fields.DialogueText: The long and the short of it is that a moderately large Morgana presence got diverted en route to the ongoing mess around Gibraltar.
Fair enough.
I'm not sure that's healthy, even for a Belle, but I'll let it slide.
The Spanish were afraid they were going to break for Barcelona or Valencia to feed, but instead they've gone quiet.
I wouldn't expect that to last long.
No. The big question is whether they're doubling back toward us or making for North Africa.
Je comprends. One thing at a time, though - that bundle of trouble we were expecting from the Ligurian Sea?
You're picking them up?
Oui. No helpful radio calls this time, though.
Keeps us on our toes.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? You wanted to see me?
Yeah. I don't know if you were aware, but I spent several hours today being shouted at over the radio by various French authorities.
That sounds extremely unpleasant!
It would probably save us both some time if you dropped the wide-eyed naïf routine.
Mais, Capitaine, it wouldn't be a show without the opening act.
Uh-huh.
Eh, bien. They're annoyed with my proposals to help Majorca, I take it?
They're annoyed that you *have* proposals to help Majorca. It's officially a Spanish problem, though a couple of people opined the Italians were free to help if they wanted.
Capitaine, it's not like I'm talking about anything absurd. You've seen the reports from Palma - the mist is everywhere, Morgana bombing was severe, medical services are overwhelmed.
I'm talking about coordinating with the Spanish to escort whatever medical relief and humanitarian aid they're able to provide. If the enemy is still lurking in the area...

Fields.MenuText: You really should've talked to me before trying to wrangle the admirals.
I get it.
Yeah, well - that backfired.

Fields.DialogueText: Enh. I wanted to be able to give you a detailed proposal, not just a vague idea. The idiots in charge - pardonnez-moi, "Command," my tongue slipped - could have helped with that.
Oui? I'm glad somebody does.
I'll let that tongue-slip slide.
Merci.
The way this generally works is that the affected nation devises a plan and submits formal requests to the League and to the nations of origin of other ships if they need assistance.
Rubbish.
Pardon?
If a volcano were exploding under Palma-
Statistically unlikely, but carry on.
We wouldn't be expected to sit back and watch people burn until the Spanish asked for help with evacuations. Not if we were right there!

Fields.MenuText: I take your point.
You could make an argument that volcanos are exploding everywhere.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Capitaine, I hate to interrupt a fascinating conversation, but...
Morganas?
Oui.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We're not exactly "right there," though.

Fields.DialogueText: We're heading west, Capitaine?
We are. We're hugging the French coastline, but if we get calls for help as we approach Spanish waters... well, it's what the Neutrality Fleet is for.
Assuming Franco cares enough to do anything at all.

Fields.MenuText: One thing at a time.
You're kind of a grumpy person, aren't you?
I'm not necessarily talking about calls for help from the Spanish government, Jeanne.

Fields.DialogueText: Pas du tout! I'm just selective in how I display my native cheerfulness.
Oui, oui.
Ah. Pardonnez-moi, Capitaine.
I shouldn't be so... churlish. I do see that you're doing what you can, and I *am* grateful.

Fields.MenuText: You're welcome.
Ah, you're frustrated because you want to help people. I get it.
Nothing to be grateful for. We're all doing what we can.

Fields.DialogueText: I... attendez. Capitaine? I'm getting a message from our scouts. We have company coming.
Right. Let's show them how hospitable we can be.
@BATTLE
Non, non, non! That was Bali, not Honolulu! Where has my memory gone?
You weren't awake yet, right? I thought Belles' memories of times when they were just ships - no offense - were just generally kind of vague.
Oui. But I *try* to remember. I try so hard!
You know Belles... who we are is shaped by our names, oui? Even more than with you mother-born folks.
My namesake was a farmer's daughter. She was fairly widely traveled for her time and place, I suppose - but me? I've been around the world.
It's been such a gift, Capitaine. It's been so much more than I could ever say I've earned. And the people I've served with? The people I've helped to train? Lions.

Fields.MenuText: Flattery accepted.
And now you're sailing back and forth in the Mediterranean.
I've seen your service history. I don't think anyone would say you've taken more than you've given.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, oui. Smirk all you like.
It's where France needs me. Where the world needs me, I hope.
Merci. You're very kind.
You know, we should have done this sooner.
What? Talk?
Yeah. Get to know each other.
You say that now, Capitaine, but I'm really not a very interesting person. Now that I've exhausted all my good stories, you have nothing to look forward to from our future conversations but tedium.

Fields.MenuText: Uh-huh.
Tedium sounds great, actually. I could use more tedium.
Well, I can always move on to one of the other ships in the fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: Charming.
When you put it that way...
I suppose I should be flattered by the scornful disbelief?
You know, you haven't told me much about yourself in all this.

Fields.MenuText: Raised by wolves.
Rocketed to Earth as a baby from a doomed world.
It's late, and it's a long story.

Fields.DialogueText: Uh-huh.
*ALARM*
Ah, merde. Here we go again.
@BATTLE
Jeanne! I know you're off-duty, but I need you on the bridge in five minutes!
What's wrong?
The Mallorca Morgana group just became a lesser problem. A significant force breached our Suez barricade and seems to be tracking west along the North African coast.
Reports out of Alexandria are garbled - but bad. Basically any west and central Mediterranean fleet assets not tasked with Gibraltar patrols are to converge at Tripoli.
Merde.
Yeah.
But, Capitaine, there are still so many loose Morgana groups in the region - we'll be leaving so much undefended.

Fields.MenuText: Orders are orders.
Hopefully most of them will follow us. A big League presence might seem like a gourmet meal.
Don't worry. If we have to, we can change our plans as the situation develops.

Fields.DialogueText: Eugh.
C'est possible.
D'accord.
Before we set the new course, Capitaine...?
Yes?
Morganes en route.
Aren't they always?
@BATTLE
Capitaine? I know speed is an issue, but I've had another call from a Delusion group - I think I know where to reach them.
Definitely worth doing. You don't sound enthusiastic, though.
C'est épuisant - exhausting. She desperately wants to know what God says to me when we talk, and the longer I can keep *her* talking the more I can learn about where she is and what she's doing.
Sorry. What God says to you when you talk?
Could you please not ask me to follow up on that part right now? I already get a dozen polite letters from HMS Belfast a week about it.

Fields.MenuText: Understood.
It's not exactly a revelation that you're religious, Jeanne.
Okay. But if it turns out this ship has a hotline to the Almighty and I wasn't aware, I'm going to be annoyed.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci.
Just... later, all right?
D'accord.
Right. Ship's Belle, if you'd be so good as to point us toward Delusion...
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Do you have a minute to talk?
Absolutely. About?
Let's start with my prayer book.
Okay?
It's not a prayer book. I slapped a fake cover over Nin's "D.H. Lawrence: An Unprofessional Study."
Huh.
Capitaine, if the French people need me to look like a saint, if it's good for morale, I'll try. Happily.
But I don't have any special insights, or any powers any other Belle doesn't. And if I were to talk to God - not saying that I do - I'm pretty sure His voice has never rung in my ears.
Honestly, I think I'm better off. The original Jeanne's life isn't one I envy.

Fields.MenuText: Got it.
Listen, while you're under my command, you don't have to pretend to be something you're not.
Methinks the lady doth protest too much.

Fields.DialogueText: Mon Dieu - and I use the phrase ironically - you sound like Belfast.
... I'll stop.
Merci, Capitaine.
That's like telling your officers they don't have to wear uniforms, Capitaine. Being "Jeanne the inspiration" is part of my duties.
But thank you.
So. How's the book?
I was hoping it would be smuttier.
Heh.
*ALARM*
Right. Here we go again.
@BATTLE
Capitaine... there's another Delusion out there. Yammering at me.
It's more than just her.
Je sais, je sais.
And it's worse than that - our unified front for this operation is dissolving.
A good chunk of the British destroyers are falling back to defend Malta, the Italians are frantically trying to minimize civilian casualties around Catania...
And *we* have the Tunisian Protectorate to cover.
Hopefully that means the Morgana push is losing cohesion, too. But...
*sigh*
Sorry. Does Delusion have anything interesting to say?
She wants me to tell her why God wants her to blow up the world. She says she doesn't want to, you understand, but "the most severe angels of time and distance" are screaming at her all the time.

Fields.MenuText: Huh.
As a rule, when Morganas spend a lot of time talking, I suspect a trap.
Is there anything there we can use against her?

Fields.DialogueText: Well said, Capitaine.
This isn't doing wonders for my morale, Capitaine, mais... I don't see how it could be a trap. She's not trying to make us *do* anything.
I've tried passing along different "orders from God."
And?
It usually leads to Delusions shooting at me.
Fair enough.

Fields.MenuText: Can you block her out when she starts getting to you?
Yeah. Give her time.
Right. Thank you for putting up with it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's better to try to learn from her, surely.
Not if it's causing you distress.
It's fine, Capitaine. But thank you.
Hm.
It seems like part of the job.
Is she close enough to worry about?
Not really, Capitaine. I think she's closer to the Italian forces at Sicily than to us.
... Though there is something coming from the east.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine. Comment puis-je vous aider?
I'm not here for any particular reason - just stretching my legs. A few crew members have told me you're praying for guidance?
... I'm wondering if we should go to Malta.
Work with the British, try to lure in the Morganas, maybe bring the Italians in from the north when the enemy is worn down?
Oui! Exactement! You have a sharp mind, Capitaine!
What's wrong?
Hopefully nothing. But... I should probably tell you that I've been hearing rumors that we might be called back to Marseille.
Those Morganes from the west? They're moving along the coast after all?
I think it's more that there are people in high office that you could be...
Hell, I can't find a delicate way to say it. There's a faction in France that seems obsessed with bringing you into the land war. And politics, I guess.
In theory, you wouldn't be in violation of Zurich - you wouldn't be shooting at anybody. But radio interviews, posters, hosting symbolic events...
I see. And who would be putting the words in my mouth?

Fields.MenuText: Not me.
You don't sound pleased.
It's fair to say that the people most invested in this idea are looking to stamp out "Bolshevism" in France, if that's what you're asking.

Fields.DialogueText: How do we stop this from happening?!
Capitaine, I will happily fight for France. I would tear up the Zurich Agreement today, if asked!

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
That's not something I particularly want to hear.

Fields.DialogueText: Je suis désolée. But it's true! I'd risk seeing the world burn rather than do nothing while barbarians with tanks sullied Paris.
But putting down my guns and being a mouthpiece for fat old men who want to hide behind the image of a teenage girl who burned at the stake? Non! NON!

Fields.MenuText: It isn't happening yet.
I'm not sure where the "fat" and the "old" are coming from, but okay.
Take a deep breath, Jeanne.

Fields.DialogueText: Please, make this go away, Capitaine. It's why you're here. It's why you were chosen.
Jeanne...
Merde. Enemy inbound, Capitaine. We can talk strategy later.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? I wanted to apologize for the other day.

Fields.MenuText: That's a mature attitude to take, and I appreciate it. But I don't know what you're apologizing for.
What did you do and how bad are the consequences?
Huh. Okay.

Fields.DialogueText: I shouldn't have said you were chosen to... what, protect me from our superior officers? It was presumptuous. And stupid. Pardonnez-moi.

Fields.MenuText: You were frustrated. It's fine.
You weren't wrong, though. If we're given... improper orders, it's my job to make our disagreements known.
I can honestly say that made no impression on me at the time.

Fields.DialogueText: Besides, you're the one that chose me. I can't really take issue with what criteria you used.
What? Morganas?
Quoi? Non, I was just...
Merde. You're good.
Capitaine, I'm afraid you're needed on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? If you're looking for La Pucelle de la Mer, she's below decks.
I know. Looking for supplies we can spare - the people along the Tunisian coast are struggling these days.
We're struggling here, too.
You have an objection, Matelot?
Non, Captaine! If we have the protection of a living saint... well, it would be rude to complain about her being saintly.
... I have kind of a strange question for you. Have you ever actually had a conversation with Jeanne?
Non, Capitaine. You know her. She stands apart from the rest of us.

Fields.MenuText: That's the way she seems to like it, yes.
You'd be surprised. She's actually really approachable.
So, basically, she probably has deeper conversations with Delusion than with her own crew.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I wouldn't think she enjoys it, Capitaine.
To you, maybe. You're the next best thing to God on this ship.
No one takes it personally, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Hm.
Yeah, you're in line for a promotion.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
Right. Thanks, Matelot - now get to where you need to be.
@BATTLE
Jeanne?
Oh, bonjour, Capitaine. What can I do for you?
Am I interrupting a paperwork session?
Non. *sigh* I am finally defeated, Capitaine. I'm agreeing to fill out a questionnaire for Belfast in exchange for her help in getting British assistance to Tunisia.
Point 1: I'm pretty sure Belfast would help you anyway.
Point 2: I'm not sure there's anything she can do. Bad as things are here, they're probably even worse in Egypt, which is always going to be a higher priority for London.
... I'm writing the damn letter anyway.

Fields.MenuText: Not saying you shouldn't.
It's your stamp.
Belfast'll be pleased.

Fields.DialogueText: The price I have to pay.
Anyway, Capitaine - puis-je vous aider?
I just wanted to give you an early glimpse into the afternoon briefing. The good news is that a propaganda tour in the Côte d'Azur is off the table for now.
Dieu merci.
Don't be too relieved - it's mostly because the situation in North Africa is so bad. Those Morganas to the west you were worried about have made their way to Morocco and western Algeria.
And rumor has it that the Italians are covering up reports of Morganas trying to build some kind of fortified installation off the Libyan coast.
And, of course, Morgana traffic through Suez is still at something like 170% what it was before the current crisis started.
The Brits are talking about diverting ground forces to put more pressure on them as they glide on through. And that's not easily done.
However I can help, Capitaine...
That's something I've been thinking about, actually. This channel of communication you've got going with Delusion - in your judgment, is that something we can use?
Capitaine?
Disinformation. Do you think we can convince her that there's some amazingly rich target somewhere? If we could bring together a significant chunk of the enemy forces at a place of our choosing...
Je comprends.
You're not enthusiastic.
The enemy knows that Delusion is... what she is, Capitaine. The ones smart enough to care - they wouldn't trust whatever messages she might babble. Who would?
Right.
And she would never trust me again.

Fields.MenuText: That trust is only an asset if we're prepared to use it, Jeanne.
You think she trusts you now?
It's Delusion. She might not even know she'd been played.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. Je sais.
... I honestly don't know.
She's not well, Capitaine - but she's not stupid.
... Right. Tell me why this is bothering you.
It's not.
Uh-huh.
... Capitaine? We may have to continue this conversation another time.
Should I be running to the bridge?
Walking energetically, perhaps.
@BATTLE
May I make a couple of awkward observations?
Non.
Non?
... You can. I just wanted to see the look on your face.
Right. Treasure the memory always.
First observation. It strikes me that the Neutrality Fleet doesn't have a great support system in place for Belles.
You don't have specialized advocates, you don't have chaplains who understand where you come from...
I'll bet you a week's pay that you've never heard one of us ask for any of that.

Fields.MenuText: Your salary or mine?
Point.
Yeah. Because you're all stubborn and self-sacrificing.

Fields.DialogueText: Yours. Maybe I could afford to take a vacation.
I can't count the ways in which you're being overly optimistic there.
Now, a lot of Belles turn to their sister ships when they need to talk.
You're going to observe that I don't have one of those.
I am. Actually, I've been asking around, and it seems like you don't have any particularly close Belle friendships, either.
Which brings me to my second observation. From what I know about Belfast, I don't think she's harassing you about your religious beliefs because she likes putting you on the spot.
I would guess that she's trying to draw you out into a conversation because she thinks you could use a friend. And possibly because she's a little bit strange.
My third observation is that you've got your crew thinking you're constantly communing with God in His Heaven on their behalf, and that most of them adore you enough to gratefully leave you to it.

It strikes me as possible that you have never, in your whole waking life, had conversations with *anybody* that were longer and deeper than the ones you have with the crazy Morgana trying to kill you.
Well, if you're here to depress me, Capitaine...
I'm not, Jeanne. I have no doubts about your loyalty, and I don't care that you're a private person.

Fields.MenuText: As long as it doesn't get in the way of your duties, anyway.
Whatever makes you happy.
Honestly, I'm in a similar boat. So to speak.

Fields.DialogueText: I just want you to know that I've noticed all this stuff. And I like you. And I'm here to talk if you ever-
Capitaine.
Something's coming. We've lost radio contact with the mainland. I think something very bad is happening.
... Hell.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Another enemy fleet!
Dammit - we barely got the fires out from the last one.
@BATTLE
I want a preliminary damage report within the next half-hour, people! I don't think the Morganas are going to give us a lot of time to relax!
Capitaine, radio contact with Tunis is... well, it's spotty, but we've gotten the basic facts.
Which are?
Mist intensity is way up. The enemy seems to be making a grab for the island of Djerba.
The Italians seem to be conceding that the Morganes have erected some kind of refueling station somewhere off the coast in eastern Libya - which means they can support more aggressive measures here.

Fields.MenuText: Right. New rule: destroying Morgana infrastructure is job one.
Which means we can't rule out weather modification either. Great.
Any word on civilian casualties?

Fields.DialogueText: D'accord.
It doesn't sound good, Capitaine.
Jeanne, I need you to help get stable radio contact back. At this point, we either find a way to get the British and the Italians back on-team or we write off hundreds of miles of coastline.
Right away, Capitaine!
Capitaine? You're off the radio. Do we have a plan?
We have a proposal. I don't know if the Marine Nationale is going to go for it. I don't even know if you're going to go for it.
If it's about Delusion, Capitaine, I promise you-
It's not. The proposal is that we leave the Tunisian coast and try to take the pressure off Malta.
If we're successful, British forces rendezvous with Italian forces and head for Egypt - where they try to sink enough Morganas around the Canal to cut off enemy reinforcements from the Red Sea.
Meanwhile, *we* double back on our own to eliminate the enemy fuel depot, or baby port, or whatever the hell it is in Libyan waters, weakening all the local packs.
I assume a lot of the eastern Morgana forces would concentrate on Egypt - but some would be after us. Along with all the haunters in the west.
Assuming they don't just pillage Algeria and Tunisia while we're distracted.
There are a lot of them, Jeanne. They can probably do both.
But if we can keep them from digging in, I think we win. I don't think this is organized behavior so much as a perfect storm. Hit them hard enough, they'll go back to disorganized packs.
Unless they don't.

Fields.MenuText: Don't make me be cheerful for both of us.
Unless they don't.
We'll deal with it if it happens.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Is the Neutrality Fleet's support structure for captains any better than it is for Belles?

Fields.MenuText: A bit.
I've never had time to check.
Enh. At least we've got each other.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad to hear it, Capitaine. Truly.
I know what that's like.
Ah. Oui.
You know what I could really use right now, though?
... Unless you're about to say "Morganes from the southeast," I'm afraid you're going to be disappointed.
Figures.
@BATTLE
We're leaving Tunisian waters, Capitaine. Do you think they'll ever forgive us?

Fields.MenuText: If we're fast enough.
This benefits them as much as anyone.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. If it works.

Fields.MenuText: We're sailing into a death trap, Jeanne. One worry at a time.

Fields.DialogueText: At least the fight is something we can control.
Have you heard from Delusion lately? Is she still in the area?
Je pense que oui. Probably. But with radio signals being hard to receive...
I know you have misgivings, but we might end up trying to make use of that.
It's not like I think she's my friend, Capitaine.
... There's just a part of me that wishes I could help her.

Fields.MenuText: Before blowing her up?
If you ever have any ideas, I'll listen.
I'd stop listening to that part of you.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui.
Merci, Capitaine. I'm not optimistic.
... Well, you never know. It's a strange world out there.
@BATTLE
I really think there's a part of her that hates what she's doing. She's just... not as strong as the demons in her head.
I know it's not in my power to change that, though. I do.
That's Malta ahead, Capitaine. I don't know if you can see it through the mist.
A lot of history here. The bloody parts were particularly bloody.
I assume Morganas are close?
Vous supposez correctement, Capitaine.
Radio is useless, but I can sense British Belles as well. I presume they can find me too.
I can't tell you how uncomfortable it makes me having to trust that they care if I live or die, by the way.

Fields.MenuText: I think it's technically the Germans you should be worried about.
A few things have changed since the fifteenth century, Jeanne.
If we sink all the Morganas ourselves, it shouldn't be a problem.

Fields.DialogueText: Remind me to tell you about my feelings about Isabeau of Bavaria someday.
Oui. And some haven't.
D'accord.
... Any sign of the enemy?
Oui. Santa Marija watch over us.
Really?
When in Malta...
@BATTLE
Capitaine - the radio's back. And, for the moment, Delusion isn't blanketing the airwaves with shouting about how I don't even know the birds are controlling me.
Birds?
I think she's talking about angels. Il est difficile d'être certain.
Oh... kay. I'm honestly surprised you're not more enthusiastic about the idea of shutting her up for a while.
That said, if we have a window to communicate with Malta, I'm going to take it. We need the British fleet moving.
Is something wrong, Capitaine? Beyond the usual, I mean.
This rain wasn't predicted. If the Morganas are screwing with the weather, our jobs are only going to get harder the longer we wait.
... Merde.

Fields.MenuText: Shocking language from a living saint.
Well said.
It gets better. Remember that we're the ones who would be attacking their storm-builder.

Fields.DialogueText: The original Jeanne was a soldier. I'm sure she'd understand.
Really?
Non.
I take back everything I ever said about talking to you being good for my morale.
... I don't remember you ever saying anything like that.
I just wanted to be sure.
Capitaine! We have... non... oui. Aircraft carrier, incoming!
No chance you're seeing Ark Royal? Okay - at least this weather's making it hard for the enemy, too.
@BATTLE
The British fleet is now officially out of my hearing range, Capitaine. God willing, they're on their way to a quick and brutal victory in Egypt.
Assuming the Italians are still willing and able to offer support.
You think they won't be?
I hope they will. But nobody in Malta was able to tell us much about how the Italians are doing in Libya, and our own intelligence is several days old.
They'll be at the rendezvous. I have faith.

Fields.MenuText: Glad to hear it.
Faith is great, but I'd rather have decent intel.
Yeah - but, apparently, you're being controlled by birds.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine. Thank you so much for that.
D'accord.
Is Delusion still hovering around where you can't find her and shouting at you?
Non. She may not be following - I don't think she likes stormy weather.
Why is she so fixated on you, anyway? Is she obsessed with the historical Jeanne? Or is it just that - and I say this respectfully - you're the only Belle crazy enough to talk to her?
Could we not use the word "crazy," Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. Figure of speech.
Sore point?

Fields.DialogueText: ... I told you once I don't hear God's voice in my ear. And that's true.
But sometimes there's...
The first time I heard your name, there were lights. No one else could see them, but I could. And there was a sound like bells ringing, and I knew you were supposed to be my captain.
I just knew it.
You were right, before. I'm not particularly close to most other Belles. But I've heard some of them talk about how they chose their commanding officer, and it's all so... rational.
And Belfast's letters. Someone asked her if she thought she was an angel, and she makes *lists*. "These are the things I do that seem supernatural." Like she's talking about groceries!
When I'm out there on the deck with my not-smutty-enough book, sometimes I see colors that aren't there. Sometimes I smell things that aren't there. Roses.
I thought for a while that I might have, je ne sais pas, the Belle equivalent to a concussion. But, no, I think being named after Jeanne just comes with a kind of wildness. In my mind.

Fields.MenuText: Okay.
Have you ever talked to a doctor?
Clearly we need to get you smuttier books.

Fields.DialogueText: "Okay?"
Okay.
Bien sûr. He can't find anything wrong with me, and suggests that I just learn to enjoy mental states that some people buy rare mushrooms to achieve.
... Yeah, that sounds like our doctor, all right.
Ha!
Do you think maybe it could be spiritual? For real?
... Again, Capitaine, "divine visitations" didn't end well for the original Jeanne.
You have much bigger guns than she did.
... Speaking of which...
I suppose we were about due.
@BATTLE
Do you?
As long as you're fit for duty - and you clearly are - my opinion doesn't matter.
Capitaine... you may want to come up to the bridge.
We've found the refueling station?
Oui. At the heart of the storm, as you'd expect. From what I can see, the effects on the Libyan coastline have been... destructive.
Tell me we have the firepower to break this thing.
It looks barely armored, Capitaine. I assume the enemy's Tunisian raids were meant to collect more steel, but...

Fields.MenuText: We got in their way.
They couldn't get as much as they needed.
Probably wisest not to make assumptions, Jeanne.

Fields.DialogueText: I take it the thing is guarded?
Oui. Bien sûr. A Vanity group - and we know there have been other groups active in the area as well.
And the weather will be trying to kill us, too. Fantastic.
There's nothing for it, though. I suggest we hit the Vanity group, expend as much ammunition as we have left on the Morgana platform, and then run as fast as we can toward Tripoli to restock.
You think Tripoli will have supplies to spare? The lines to Italy have been fairly badly shredded over the last couple of weeks.
And Malta's been cleaned out, too. I know. We'll just have to see how it goes.
Good luck out there, Jeanne.
Bonne chance à vous aussi, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine!
Y'know, a scandalized matelot told me you were dancing on deck, but I didn't quite believe it until I saw it with my own eyes.
Regardez le ciel, Capitaine!  We broke the storm! No matter what else may happen, we did that much for the people of Libya. And eastern Tunisia!

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. But we don't know how the operation at Suez went. Or if it's still going.
Let's just never talk about that storm again.
Yes, we did.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be so negative!
You were very green when the waves were big, weren't you?
I had the presence of mind not to look in the mirror at the time.
... It's good to see you happy.
Dance with me.
I don't know - the crew's pretty scandalized by all this revelry already.
Pff! Just for ten minutes, let's say I'm not Jeanne d'Arc and you're not the Capitaine, and we're free to dance. I dare you!
Oh, if it's a dare, Mademoiselle, then this is a whole different thing. You might want to stand back.
Ha! Show me what you've got!
Ah. So here's where you've been hiding.
I have not been "hiding," Capitaine. I've been reviewing reports.
Sealed in my quarters. With the lights out.
I do my best reviewing in low-stimulus environments, Capitaine.
Uh-huh.
... Fine. The crew is looking at me differently now. It seems like a good idea to be aloof until they stop.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. It's probably permanent.

Fields.DialogueText: Eugh.

Fields.MenuText: Your call.
Do you have to clutter up my quarters while you do it, though?

Fields.DialogueText: C'est vrai. All mine.
This isn't clutter, Capitaine. These are the personal touches your quarters have so desperately needed.
It's a stack of marked-up requisition forms.
See? Homey!
... Capitaine?
Jeanne?
Morganes incoming.
Of course there are.
@BATTLE
Un moment, Capitaine. I'll just clean up my mess, and you can get some rest.
It's fine. It really is. And you fought very well today, I'll have you know.
Merci. You, too!
Any chance the radio interference has cleared up with the Morganas gone?
I think so, actually. We're trying to contact Tripoli now.
... I was happy to see that the crew seems not to have given up on me.
For letting your hair down for five minutes? Pf.

Fields.MenuText: You need to trust your people, Jeanne. They're not fickle.
I promise you, the more someone gets to know you, the more wonderful you seem.

Fields.DialogueText: You have to say that, though. You're the captain.
Some day we'll pencil in another five minutes when you're not Jeanne and I'm not "the Captain" and I'll say the same damn thing.
I'll look forward to that.
You and me both. For now, though, let me get those requisition forms and-
Oh, tell me we're not under attack again.
Non. But... Capitaine, we've had word from Tripoli.
The operation at Suez failed. More Morganes are coming, Capitaine.
... A lot more.
